"The final ending of a species." REVISED: "The final ending for this species and countless others due to the pernicious nature of mankind." For me, this is the ULTIMATE definition of SADNESS. That is, the realization that mankind is the only lifeform ever to exist that is directly responsible for the extinction of other life. Despite understanding we are the cause of a mass extinction emergency, except for the noble efforts of a few people and organizations, no meaningful and coordinated global action is being taken to reverse the process. A few years ago, the United Nations Environmental Program published the results of a multi-year study that concluded Mankind is responsible for causing the extinction of between 150 and 200 species every 24 hours- yes, 150 to 200. Change will not happen until such point in time as we realize that our own extinction is imminent, but by then it will be too late. Take Donald Trump. This destroyer of worlds occupies the most powerful position in the world and he is working overtime to destroy the natural world. Just last week, despite news that America's wild bird population has declined 70% since 1980, Trump is planning on, for the first and only time ever, to open America's wildlife refuges to hunting!!!!! These sites were first established by Republican President Teddy Roosevelt to provide wildlife with a few protected areas free from harm. Just so sick.....

That bit about the antelope fawn and the cheetah.  Yes, if you've been watching the fawn and sort of getting to know it, seeing it interact with its mother and be part of the herd and such, it's very easy to want to shoo away the cheetah.  You wouldn't want to see the fawn get killed and eaten, after all.  But you must also consider that the cheetah doesn't want to see her cubs starve to death because some human spoiled her hunt.  It's easy to see the cheetah as evil for killing, but in the end, the cheetah and her cubs have the same right to try and survive as the antelope and her fawn.

Now I've watched "Planet Earth II". Unfortunately, I haven't seen the first one yet, because I hadn't had that much of interest in Wild Life as much as I had in Cosmology and Quantum Physics at that time, not that I don't like it or watch it at all, but maybe of a less interest.
Anyway, what is great about this series is the way Mr. David and his crew managed to capture the "real" wildlife that we didn't have the chance to see at all! Even in other natural life TV series!
Also, the show's versatility adds a lot to it, fulfilling its purpose of clarifying natural life's fluctuating circumstances, sometimes a wide smile is drawn onto your face, sometimes you feel bad for that poor dead bird and sometimes the eagle's swiftness leaves you astonished, and that is the real life and its cycle of events!
I fell into the idea that animals are entirely stupid and selfish, or at least I didn't know whether that was the case or not, but "Planet Earth" through those captivating scenes, succeeded to open my eyes to the huge world we are living in and may not feel its wonderfulness.

It seems only natural that if the universe tends towards dissipating all energy into pure equilibrium, that little machines like us would evolve on planets orbiting stars that increase the rate of entropy. Most of us wish to protect life, to increase entropy further. We also seek more food to convert the chemical energy to kinetic and heat energy. The universe is suicidal. Actually, the reason why record derives from "cor" is because in the ancient times it was a common belief that the heart was the place where memories were kept. The verb "to remember" in italian translates to "ricordare", coming from Latin "recordari". Let's keep it real shall we?

An huge proportion of jobs are totally superfluous. If they do not consist in one variation or another on "digging holes and filling them in again" then they could be rationalised out by improved efficiency.

Then there are the service industries, that are completely unnecessary, and industries that are created, or retained at artificially labour intensive levels...

Why?

The average human being has deep psychological and emotional needs to feel useful and productive (even if, in real terms, they are neither) as well as to indentify themselves with, and define themselves in terms of, a work related social heirarchy. As a result one of the most significant factors in obtaining and sustaining political popularity and power is employment creation.

Governments pour huge sums of money, directly and indirectly, into creating totally superfluous employment. It would probably cost less, in the long term, to pay out welfare benefits but at the expense of creating a frustrated, dissatisfied and volatile society.

A lot of autistics not only lack those deep psychological and emotional needs, but also the social skills to function in the workplace. As a result, for them, the very same workplace that most people need to feel comfortable and fulfilled, is an intolerable torture...a "cruel and unusual punishment" if you like...

I think the question of deciding to interfere or not while filming predator brings up a good point. You can't save the prey because if you scare off the predator it could lead to a chain of events where eventually the species of the prey would begin to die of over population in the region it's in. If you choose to scare away a predator you may leave that predator with no food at all to feed to itself or family. Some predators cannot resort to eating vegetation because unlike humans they can't change their diet.

I'd say there's a very distinct line to define life.  In my opinion, life is anything containing a blueprint (such as genetic code) that defines the way an object is composed, and where that object's goal is to refine it's blueprint to perfection.  Perfection is a relative perspective.  Some living things care about quantity over quality, or robustness over efficiency.  In the case of organic life, it is too difficult for a living being to correct it's own composure, so it's easier for them to start a fresh batch, via reproduction.  In the case of animals or sexual microbes, they can intentionally seek out a mate they deem good enough (or better) than their current selves.

We are indeed unique and the best equipped to attempt to document our observations of the current species that exist and we do kind of owe it to ourselves and our progeny to admit and acknowledge something terribly unfortunate. As we study and document and place these observations into defining strata that summarize each representatives qualities, we begin to see not only similarities and differences, but relative importances. We have to at some point ask the question: if we clear the land to the point that we can grow food to sustain us, at some point the land that we clear is altered and the previous inhabitants of that land must suffer, starve, relocate or die. At some point we clear out predators that might harm us or our offspring and with no predators, prey populations inflate to the point that their land can no longer support them and we must assume the role of the predator that we cleared out. Or, we can watch that species overpopulate and eventually starve. But we had set it in motion and it was for the sake of our loved ones. We can't honestly have our cake and eat it too. Something, somewhere will always have to suffer and die regardless of what we do or don't do. That's an unfortunate fact. To deny it is to ignore everything we've learned about nature. The only true morality will turn out to be that we must do what we must to survive and provide for our children. In our hearts we all know this is what the ultimate moral code is based on. But only man has the capacity and the curse of seeing both and feeling the haunting acknowledgement of both realities. The only other thing possible is to eliminate ourselves from the equation, but in reality, we all know that that is not going to happen.

I met david attenborough at a supermarket in London yesterday. I told him how cool it was to meet him in person, but I didn’t want to be a bore and bother him and ask him for photos or anything.
He said, “Oh, like you’re doing now?”
I was taken aback, and all I could say was “Huh?” but he kept cutting me off and going “huh? huh? huh?” and closing his hand shut in front of my face. I walked away and continued with my shopping, and I heard him chuckle as I walked off. When I came to pay for my stuff up front I saw him trying to walk out the doors with like fifteen Milky Ways in his hands without paying.
The girl at the counter was very nice about it and professional, and was like “Sir, you need to pay for those first.” At first he kept pretending to be tired and not hear her, but eventually turned back around and brought them to the counter.
When she took one of the bars and started scanning it multiple times, he stopped her and told her to scan them each individually “to prevent any electrical infetterence,” and then turned around and winked at me. I don’t even think that’s a word. After she scanned each bar and put them in a bag and started to say the price, he kept interrupting her by yawning really loudly.

Sir David was THE MAIN REASON that I became a biologist. I owe this man so much, inasmuch as he gave me the hunger to want to learn about the natural world when I was a child, and it was after watching him I decided I wanted to become a scientist. His documentaries are instrumental to my classes when I introduce my students to a new concept in biology, and even at leisure I am still happy to watch his programmes.

I was lucky enough to be lectured by this wonderful man at university a few years ago, and after his last lecture on evolution, the entire hall stood up and applauded him till our hands become red. The term "national treasure" is oft thrown about hither and yon, but Sir David is a rare breed where this term fits him like a glove.
